Well speech pathologists normally work with people with speech impediments like lisps, stuttering and voicelessness as well as speech restoration in those with strokes and helping quadriplegics and stroke victims with swallowing disorders :) We also help people with cleft palate and recent jaw or lip surgery. Vocal coaches are less scientific/medical trained and work mostly with accents, ESL learners, enunciation and actor training. Speech pathologists can do this as well, but our work is typically focussed towards medical conditions (think The Kings Speech)

Hahaha, no it's not like that really. I'm 5'3 and was the shortest one there, even shorter than the girls. If I was at least an inch or two taller I might have been able to stay. Surprisingly, they encouraged as much body positivity as they could as they worried a lot about self esteem and eating disorders. We had full classes on nutrition and we were cooked full plate meals that we had to eat everything of. The extent of what they did about my height was make sure I didn't have some sort of illness that stunted my growth since my dad is 6'1. But no, it was genetic from my mum's side of the family, they did however found out I had depression and got me help, so ayeeee. The reason they kicked me out goes a little further, ballet in Russia is heavily subsidised by the government because Vaganova should be pushing out star dancers. With my height, I never could fit that criteria. In the end, they recommended me to a bunch of other prestigious schools like SAB in the US. It all worked out for the best, I stayed in touch with my old teacher who was really happy to hear that I became a teacher.

Hey I am also bored and can't sleep here in Australia lol. :P
I guess the most fun fact about me depends on your interests. I went to the most prestigious ballet school when I was kid - Vaganova in Russia. I ended up getting 'kicked out' because I didn't grow very tall, lol (it's super competitive, out of the the thousands who apply, only around 60-80 get in, from that, only 30 graduate from the school).

I hated my husband when I first met him in high school. I thought he was a total prick. I was raised to be very courteous and polite, but he is really blunt and upfront with people who step out of line and was always getting into trouble for various things like hacking computers and telling teachers they were wrong. I ended up doing an English project with him, he invited me over to his place and he ordered us pizza and he actually DID the homework to prepare for it which surprised me. We talked and he turned out to be really nice. He ended up standing up for me when a teacher told me off for using rainbow colours in my book (I colour code my notes, still do) because I was one of the few out gay kids, he got detention for that and came out to me that day. A few weeks later he invites me over to finish up the project and then asks me out. Been together for the past 7 years and counting. :)

My partner was in the army so I can sympathise. It was really, really hard for me when he was gone. I was studying at the time and working, as long as I kept occupied I could get through each day a little easier.
I guess my advice would be to occupy your time with something - cook more for yourself, go to the gym or schedule daily walks, read more books, watch movies, pick up a new hobby like painting or something. Just fill your days with small goals and things to do. You will still miss him, but you'll miss him more when you're in an unproductive rut

No worries. :) I think politics isn't black and white. You can't just throw all of your eggs in one basket with a candidate, it's more of a sliding scale. But yeah. I'm not trying to convince you and neither are you me. :) Cheers bro

So you're saying that because other companies do it, it is okay for the president of the United States to do so as well?
The tax rates of the United States is on par to my own country's, if not less harsh (our tax rates hit up to 45%). Not to mention, there are things called tax breaks to ease the market and allow businesses to flourish. Lowering US taxes won't solve the issue of people not paying taxes, it didn't work in Russia (they lowered it to 13%) and it sure as heck won't work in the US. Because in the end it will still always be cheaper to get mass-produced products in China than the US where the costs and standards of living are higher, as are the wages and materials.
The US needs to refocus its spending. Rather than waste so much of its GDP on failing wars, it should invest in infrastructure and innovation. Not bringing back decade old trades that will all be consumed by automation in another 5-10 years. These are very expensive short term solutions. Take it from someone who has lived almost 6 years under an incompetent government whose answer to increasing jobs and growth was cutting jobs in health, teaching etc, and advertising work to people with visas. Because it's cheap. Not because it's sustainable. And that's been Trump and the Republican's line for ages.

WRITING.TITLE: Advancement in specialised nursing?
WRITING.TEXT:

I'm really keen on working in perioperative nursing, especially in anaesthetics and instrument circulation, and hope to become a nurse practitioner some day, but I am a little confused as to how exactly you get into these sectors? I know you need to get into a transitional program, but exactly how common are they and how are you selected?

Suicide helplines are not solely for people about to kill themselves. They are also for people who are depressed or anxious, because they are at risk. Volunteers are actually often qualified mental health professionals, not necessarily psychologists, but range from psych grads, to nurses and counsellors.
have you tried calling a suicide helpline? It really doesn't sound like you have exhausted your options

Have you tried calling a suicide hotline? They can direct you to a cost effective therapist close to you. There is also online counselling available.
Also this isn't true for everyone. Not everyone on this site is American. A lot of us are European and Australian and have free access to public health schemes which include psychologists and psychiatrists

It's about a 6 minute train ride from Central station. Platform 19. There are also buses which run into Newtown as well such as the 423. They take 13 minutes. A little longer now since the roads they take are now single lane due to installation of a tram system. Train is more reliable. But you will need to get an Opal card. You top up money to this card or link it to your credit card and it will charge you for train, bus and ferry trips by you tapping on and off stops.
It's also where all the cool food like cronuts and $12 ice tea is. And nice boutiques and book stores. It's great for a shop during the day and a dine and pub crawl at night.

I was born in Moscow, Russia. Moved to Sydney at the age of 7 with my parents. Stayed in Sydney ever since. It's a weird city, it's both progressive and corporatised and renting here costs a kidney, buying a place costs your soul. But I doubt I could ever leave. It's such an oxymoronic place where you both have amazing chill out zones with the beaches and the farmers markets and casual eateries, but then you have the really fast paced inner city, with rich cultural and ethnic diversity.

While this is true, the article does not show exactly how much progestin is needed to produce these effects. Going from my biology study, synthetic progesterone in oral contraceptives is much higher than in naturally occurring progesterone. There aren't a great deal of human studies on the role of progesterone and sex, at least not what I can find, but it is common for women to report increased sexual responsiveness during these times so I guess we can still only speculate on whether the findings of the original article are conferring something which could be naturally occurring, but using a manipulation of contraceptives which can be more controlled.
